Kinda jumping in in the middle here, but the media port is probably for their software and the web port is for accessing it via a browser. You shouldn't need to do anything to access it if you're on a private LAN.
DSL can be configured either way. If you're with a big ISP it's probably dynamic unless you're paying for a static
Do you know what private IP on your local network it's getting and if so can you ping it from a computer on the same LAN?
The Nightowl is configured to connect via PPPOE?
So you're connecting the Nightowl directly to a bridged DSL modem?
Hmm, is there a monitor attached to the Nightowl and an IR remote you can use to configure it?
yes that is how i am configuring it
There should be somewhere in the menus where you can find out what IP address you were assigned, assuming the PPPOE login was successful
I can't think of anything that the Night Owl would do that would require DNS and DNS definitely isn't required to make the PPPOE login work
Is the Night Owl the only device connected to the DSL modem or is it a DSL modem with other devices attached?

I'm trying to understand how you're connecting. Only one device should be doing the PPPOE login. If you're DSL modem is configured to function as a router as well, it is probably already doing the PPPOE login.
So there are other devices on the network?
Gotcha. Then you're not connecting it to a bridged DSL model ;)
Ideally it should probably be configured with a static. If you're going to want to allow people to connect to it from the web you're going to have to set up port forwards in the router
You'll need to assign it an address that doesn't conflict with the range being assigned by DHCP
Do you know how the private LAN is configured?
